title: R44649
content: The report examines FY2017 appropriations for the Treasury Department and its operating bureaus, including the IRS. It describes the President's budget request for Treasury in FY2017 and the current status of legislation in the House and Senate to fund the department. The report also discusses selected policy issues raised by the budget request and appropriations bills. The Treasury Department performs critical functions such as protecting the financial system, collecting tax revenue, managing federal debt, regulating financial institutions, and producing currency. The Treasury Department consists of departmental offices and operating bureaus. Departmental offices handle policy initiatives and day-to-day operations, while bureaus manage specific tasks and duties, accounting for over 95% of funding and workforce. Bureaus are divided into financial management/regulation and law enforcement, with entities like the Comptroller of the Currency and U.S. Mint involved in financial management. The Treasury Department's operating bureaus are responsible for financial management and law enforcement tasks. While most bureaus are funded through annual discretionary appropriations, the IRS stands out as it handles tax collection and enforcement. The Department of Homeland Security's establishment in 2002 reduced Treasury's direct involvement in law enforcement, with exceptions like the IRS. The Treasury Department's operating bureaus are funded through annual discretionary appropriations, except for the IRS which collects fees for its services. Treasury appropriations in FY2016 were distributed among 11 accounts, covering salaries, policy formulation, financial management, and law enforcement tasks. The Office of Terrorism and Financial Intelligence account funds programs to prevent terrorist financing and money laundering. The Department-wide Systems and Capital Investments Program account invests in technology upgrades for Treasury's operations. The Office of Inspector General account covers expenses for audits and investigations to improve efficiency. The Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration and the Special Inspector General for the Troubled Asset Relief Program conduct evaluations to improve efficiency, prevent fraud, and inform Congress about issues in Treasury operations. Their investigations focus on IRS programs and TARP management, aiming to recommend changes to address problems and deficiencies. The Special Inspector General for the Troubled Asset Relief Program (SIGTARP) evaluates the effectiveness of TARP, established by the Emergency Economic Stabilization Act. The Financial Crimes Enforcement Network (FinCEN) protects the financial system from illicit uses like money laundering and terrorist financing through the Bank Secrecy Act. FinCEN works with financial institutions and federal agencies to ensure compliance with reporting requirements. The Bureau of the Fiscal Service funds functions previously handled by separate bureaus. The Bureau of the Fiscal Service (BFS) account covers expenses related to payment policies, debt collection, financial accounting, and public debt operations. The Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau (ATTB) account pays for activities related to enforcing laws on alcohol and tobacco sales and production. The Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau (ATTB) enforces laws on alcohol and tobacco sales and production, as well as federal consumer safety laws. The Community Development Financial Institutions Fund (CDFIF) supports community development financial institutions that provide funding for affordable housing, small businesses, and community projects. The CDFIF has awarded over $2.0 billion since its creation in 1994. The Treasury Department supports institutions through various programs like the CDFI Program, Native American CDFI Assistance Program, and BEA program. They have allocated $40 billion in New Markets tax credits to CDEs. The IRS uses funds for operations, taxpayer services, and enforcement measures to improve voluntary compliance. The Obama Administration's FY2017 budget request for the Treasury Department is reviewed. The Treasury Department's budget request for FY2017 is discussed, including appropriations for the Departmental Offices (DO) account. The President's request included $334 million for DO, $5 million less than FY2016. Anticipated reimbursable expenses would bring the total DO operating budget to an estimated $437 million in FY2017. The budget request for FY2017 included $437 million in total funding. Allocations included $38 million for executive direction, $59 million for international affairs, $76 million for domestic finance, $117 million for TFI, and $43 million for Treasury management. Additionally, $22 million was designated for various programs such as financial audit, IT modernization, and critical infrastructure protection. The budget called for increases in program expansions and maintaining FY2016 levels of operation, with decreases in non-recurring expenses. The House passed a bill (H.R. 5485) on July 7, 2016 that would have provided $250 million in appropriations for the Department of Treasury in FY2017. This amount did not include funding for TFI, which was addressed in a separate account under the bill. $57 million of the recommended appropriation would have been available through the end of FY2018 for various purposes including financial audit, IT modernization, and oversight of the Gulf Coast Restoration Trust Fund. The House Appropriations Committee directed Treasury to enforce laws against wildlife trafficking and ivory poaching, submit reports on implementing the National Strategy on Wildlife Trafficking, and report on sanctions against Iran. Funding for FSOC and OFR was also addressed. The Financial Stability Oversight Council (FSOC) and the Office of Financial Research (OFR) were created by the Dodd-Frank Act. Currently, they finance their operations through fees from private institutions, giving Congress limited control. The committee directed OFR to submit quarterly budget reports and proposed bringing OFR funding into the annual appropriations process. One report will identify entities removed from the Iran sanction list in the past two years and their subsequent activities, while the other will focus on non-nuclear sanctions designations related to Iran issued by Treasury in the past three fiscal years.
